title: Mastering the Turn, Tilt & Drop in Headshot Photography
summary: Peter Hurley addresses a common mistake photographers make when posing subjects with one shoulder forward. He explains that while dropping the front shoulder accentuates the jawline, photographers often erroneously drop the camera height and tilt it to match, causing the subject to look like they are falling out of the frame. The tutorial demonstrates the correct 'un-tilt' technique to maintain a strong composition.

steps.action: Identify the common mistake: When a subject brings a shoulder forward and drops it to accentuate the jawline, photographers often drop the camera too low and tilt it to match the shoulder line.
Correct the shoulder drop: Instruct the subject to drop the front shoulder only about an inch or two to tighten the neck skin, rather than dropping it drastically.
Manage hair placement: If the subject has long hair, ensure it doesn't block the neck line when the shoulder is turned forward. Move hair behind the shoulder if necessary.
Execute the 'Un-tilt': Instead of tilting the camera to match the subject's head tilt, 'un-tilt' the camera (keep it more level) to keep the shoulders looking square in the frame.
Adjust Camera Height: Drop the camera slightly to mouth height but do not point it steeply down at the subject. Maintain a perspective that doesn't distort the body.
Review images: Compare shots where the camera followed the shoulder drop versus shots where the camera was 'un-tilted' to see the difference in body composition.

key_takeaways: Do not drop the camera height significantly to match a dropped shoulder; keep it around mouth/nose level.
The front shoulder should only drop about an inch to define the jawline; 'less is more'.
Use the 'un-tilt' technique: counter-rotate the camera against the subject's tilt to prevent the body from looking like a triangle sliding out of the frame.
Watch for hair blocking the neck line during turns and adjust accordingly.
Shooting straight on or slightly un-tilted makes the subject look slimmer and more planted in the frame compared to shooting down at an angle.
